properties.UseDescrip: Open space, degraded industrial site. Mariner's Marsh is a complex of former dry docks that are now freshwater wetlands including ten ponds, marshes, meadows, woods, and streams.
properties.History: Ten ponds were created in the early 20th century by extensive sand mining which brought the water table to the surface for ship manufactures.
properties.KnownContaminates: Limited EPA phase I and II environmental site assessments have determined a significant amount of contaminated back filling of the site subsequent to termination of manufacturing. Contaminated fill material is present in the vicinity of the former recreat
properties.OtherDescrip: Complex of freshwater wetlands and pine oak swamp hydrologically linked to Arlington Marsh. The natural integrity of the Mariner's Marsh area has been subject to industrial and illegal dumping and neglect. Dotting the park's varied landscape are ten ponds
properties.ASurvey: Alderson & Bowers 2012.

properties.PlanRegion: JAMAICA BAY STUDY AREA
properties.LocationDescrip: Peninsula in the Rockaways that juts out into the Motts Basin on the eastern shore of Jamaica Bay.
properties.Ownership: New York State Office of Parks, Recreation, and Historic Preservation, NYS Division of Lands and Forests
properties.SiteRestorationStatus: Bayswater State Park was recommended in the draft HRE in 2017 but was removed from final consideration in HRE based on the outcome of the regional Cost Effectivenes/Incremental Cost Analysis. The project can be implemented by others.
properties.CoastWetNote: Remove invasive dominated areas by re-grading and creating a tidal channel and associated salt marsh. Restoration may include creating a tidal channel of approximately 0.21 acres, approximately 2.5 acres of low marsh, and 0.4 acres of high marsh.
properties.IslandsNote: Bayswater is a major stopover point in the Atlantic Flyway for over 300 species of migratory shorebirds.
properties.ForestsNote: Restoration to approximately 0.7 acres of dune habitat and elimination of invasive-dominated communities and restoration of native vegetation communities.
properties.AquaticHabNote: Habitat improvement opportunities. Bayswater is a valuable nursery and feeding area for many finfish species. The training structures will be made of rock placed in a trapezoidal cross section. The rocks will be placed randomly within the shape to create various size interstitial spaces that can be used by various species.
properties.ShoreNote: Bank/shoreline stabilization opportunities.
properties.SedimentNote: The restoration action decreases current exposure to receptors following re-grading. Capping of upland soils with sand from the northern portion of the site with an additional 12 inches of growing medium will further reduce any remaining exposure to receptors.
properties.AccessNote: The restoration can be integrated with planned public access improvements implemented by the NYS Department of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation, as well as NYC parks plans for coastal wetland and forest restoration. The Bayswater Point site is a high visibility public park and represents an important contribution to public education and patronage opportunities.
properties.HabOther: Bayswater Point State Park is comprised of grassland, small tidal marshes, monocultures of invasive species, and native and opportunistic woody vegetation. The site contains the last patch of a mature native oak forest on Jamaica Bay. A deteriorating seawall contributes to sever shoreline erosion and loss of habitat.
properties.Flora: Mature native oak forest, rare for this area. The site is also dominated by nonnative, invasive plant species.
properties.UseDescrip: Active and passive recreation. Site is zoned vacant and completely degraded open/recreational site with parks/public lands. The surrounding land zoned vacant, 1 & 2 family residential, institutional, and open/recreational site.
properties.History: The proposed project area at Bayswater State Park was primarily salt marsh as of 1879, with four structures on site. Historical documents indicate that the predominant upland areas within the site are natural rather than fill areas.
properties.OtherDescrip: Bayswater Park has a number of special natural features including the last patch of mature native oak forests on Jamaica Bay. The ecological problems at Bayswater State Park are: presence of extensive areas of nonnative, invasive plant species and potential loss of habitat due to deteriorating seawall.
properties.HHistorical: Presence of known cultural resources in park area.  Baseline cultural resources survey and Phase IB were performed (Pan-American 1999, 2006)

properties.PlanRegion: JAMAICA BAY STUDY AREA
properties.LocationDescrip: 0.1 miles east northeast from the corner of Bayfield Avenue and Beach 65th Street.
properties.SiteRestorationStatus: Dubos Point was recommended in the draft HRE in 2017 but was removed from final consideration in HRE based on the outcome of the regional CE/ICA. The project can be implemented by others.  The project area was also included in the Rockaway/Jamaica Bay Reformulation Study.
properties.CoastWetNote: Restore marsh by creating tidal channels in an existing upland common reed stand and re-grading the area to salt marsh elevations. Tidal channels in the northern tip will also be reopened, with the addition of training structures. A total of 6.8 acres will be restored at this site including approximately 3.5 acres of low marsh, 0.6 acres of high marsh, and 0.7 acres (2,164 feet) of tidal channel.
properties.IslandsNote: Dubos Point is a major stopover point in the Atlantic Flyway for over 300 species of migratory shorebirds.
properties.ForestsNote: Restoration of approximately 2 acres of maritime forest.
properties.AquaticHabNote: Dubos Point is a valuable nursery and feeding area for many finfish species.
properties.ShoreNote: Channel modification and realignment and shoreline stabilization. Pile replacement and toe protection at north and west shorelines.
properties.SedimentNote: Chemicals concentrations measured in soil/sediment were minimal. Capping of upland soils with clean growing medium (if needed) for the restoration action would reduce any exposure to receptors in the future 2 acres of maritime forest.
properties.HabOther: Wetland, low marsh, old field, uplands. The ecological problems at Dubos Point are; presence of areas of nonnative, invasive plant species, high energy littoral zone along western and northern shorelines, mosquito infestation of local properties due to pooling water, dumped trash and debris may impede use of site, fill that removed marsh.
properties.Flora: This site contains a diverse native flora within each of the predominate cover types. The interior upland contains a diverse cover of mixed scrub shrub and old field. The scrub shrub is formed primarily by winged sumac, bayberry, black cherry, blackberry and marsh-elder mixed with common reed and goldenrods. The old field community is a mix of forbs and grasses. Predominant species include seaside goldenrod, common reed, switchgrass, common ragweed, mugwort, flat-topped goldenrod (Euthamia graminifolia) and evening primrose (Oenothera biennis). A high marsh zone of variable width is present. The predominant species include salt meadow cordgrass, seaside goldenrod, common reed, marsh orach, marsh elder and groundsel-tree. The low marsh is dominated by saltmarsh cordgrass and also includes sea lavender and glasswort.
properties.Fauna: Dubos Point is a wildlife sanctuary. The zonation of cover types from tidal marsh to upland scrub shrub and old fields provides valuable wildlife habitat within Jamaica Bay.
properties.DevelDescrip: Site is zoned degraded vacant, open/recreational site with parks/public lands. The surrounding land is zoned industrial, 1 & 2 family residential, and transportation/utilities site.
properties.UseDescrip: Dubos Point is a wildlife sanctuary. Wetland, low marsh, old field, uplands.  See site description for existing vegetation community. Site is zoned degraded vacant, open/recreational site with parks/public lands.
properties.History: The salt marsh at Dubos Point was mostly untouched until the 1920’s. Dubos Point was filled between 1912 and 1919.
properties.OtherDescrip: Dubos Point's entire shoreline is bordered by approximately 50-foot-wide bands of low marsh. Along the western and northern shorelines, old wood piles are sporadically present along the marsh edge.  Fewer piles exist along the eastern shoreline of the site.
properties.NotesRegina: Priority Site- footprint should be coordinatinated with Rockaway Reformulation

properties.CoastWetNote: Restoration and creation of approximately 12 acres of salt marsh habitat through the excavation of Phragmites, removal of debris, and re-grading to sustainable marsh elevations.
properties.ForestsNote: Preservation and restoration of existing, approximately 19 acre shrub buffer. The back slope behind the marsh should be graded to a stable slope and planted with shrub buffer. Area should be checked for invasives.
properties.ShoreNote: Removal of debris and re-grading of along 2,168 feet of shoreline to create shallow water habitat.
properties.SedimentNote: Potential removal and capping based on further sediment testing.
properties.HabOther: Estuarine - marshes, tidal waterways, tidal ponds, intertidal flats.

properties.UseDescrip: Light recreation, undeveloped parkland (GNRA). The site is zoned open/recreational site with federal lands. The surrounding land is zoned open/recreational site.
properties.OtherDescrip:
The low marsh area of this site is dominated by Spartina alterniflora, as well as other desirable marsh species along with high marsh species where there is a minimal grade change. There are two degraded marsh areas that would benefit from restoration.

properties.LocationDescrip: 0.1 miles west of the corner of Palisade Avenue and Spaulding Lane. The park lies along Palisade Avenue between 232nd and 248th Street on the Hudson River side.
properties.ProtectedInfo: Riverdale Park is designated Forever Wild by the NYC DPR. Riverdale Park is adjoined with the Alderbrook wetland and is across the street from the Raoul Wallenberg Forest.
properties.CoastWetNote: Support restoration of the ~0.7 acres freshwater wetlands at the outlet of Alderbrook in Riverdale Park. Alder brook is located at 248th and Palisades.
properties.ForestsNote: Continued support to NYC DPR NRG specific forest restoration and maintenance projects.
properties.TributaryNote: Clean and re-assess capacity of culverts connecting ~160 linear feet from Alderbrook Stream to the Hudson River.
properties.SedimentNote: Potential dredging and capping of contaminated sediment based on testing.
properties.AccessNote: Continued support to NYC DPR specific public access, greenway and bike trail projects. Plans include a connection to the Hudson River Valley Greenway.  Access to the river itself can be from the stairs at the Riverdale Station or at 254th Street.
properties.HabOther: Wetland and forested upland. The park is a haven for birds. Twenty-seven species, including the screech owl (Otus asio), have been confirmed as breeding in the park.
properties.Flora: Red oaks, black birch, black cherry, and hickory are scattered throughout the canopy. In the spring, woodland wildflowers like jack-in-the-pulpit, bloodroot, and blue violet bloom along the shaded path. Later in summer, spikenard, blue-stemmed goldenrod,
properties.DevelDescrip: Riverdale Park is undeveloped (no facilities) and designated by Parks for passive use. Residents currently use unpaved footpaths for passive recreation. The land is zoned as a transportation/utilities and open/recreational site with parks/public lands. Th
properties.OtherDescrip: Located along the Hudson River, this park contains steep-sloped deciduous forest with a creek and wetland. Although every area of Riverdale Park has been cleared at one time, the southern part is covered by the same type of forest that existed in pre-colo
properties.ASurvey: Regional data exists inclusive of this site, Alderson and Bower 2012.
properties.DEnvironment: No data obtained, Alderson and Bowers 2012.
properties.IRestoration: No data obtained, Alderson and Bowers 2012.

properties.SiteRestorationStatus: Given the proximity to JFK Airport, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey (PANYNJ) and the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) will need to be notified to ensure restoration plans are not in conflict with airport operations.
properties.CoastWetNote: Excavation of Phragmites and planting of Spartina spp. to restore approximately 3 acres of tidal wetland.
properties.ForestsNote: Preservation and restoration along approximately 20 acres of scrub shrub and woodland.
properties.AquaticHabNote: Removal of abandoned water tanks and debris and assessment of flats for composition, level of degradation and potential enhancements to increase habitat connectivity- such as addition of complex structure 3 acres of existing mudflats and shallow water.
properties.WaterNote: Re-contouring approximately 2,682 feet of the basin will increase flow to the created habitat.

properties.HabOther: This site has estuaries/marines, freshwater ponds, intertidal marshes, and emergent freshwater.
properties.Flora: The low marsh areas are approximately 20 to 50 feet wide and are dominated by saltmarsh cordgrass. These areas grade upward to an upland community dominated by common reed with small patches of shrubs and trees. The shrub areas contain sumac, black cherry
properties.UseDescrip: The site is zoned industrial. The surrounding land is zoned vacant, 1 & 2 family residential, industrial, and open/recreational site.
properties.KnownContaminates: It is listed on the New York State 303(d) TMDL list with pathogens identified as the parameter of concern and CSOs as the primary pollutant or cause.
properties.OtherDescrip: Bergen Basin is an inlet/ urban creek off of Jamaica Bay within the north-west corner of JFK Airport.  . It is a New York State Class I saline waterbody for secondary contact recreation, and fish propagation and survival. Siltation at mouth of creek has l

properties.PlanRegion: JAMAICA BAY STUDY AREA
properties.LocationDescrip: 0.1 miles west of 104th Street, Queens NY. This site consists of two locations located along Hawtree Basin. The first location is on the east bank of the creek between Davenport Street and 164th Avenue. The second and larger portion of this site is a mostly vacant parcel located between 103rd Street and Russell Street on the east, 1st Street on the south and 160th Avenue on the north. The site includes Charles Memorial Park.
properties.Ownership: NYC Parks, NYCDEP, NYSDEC, National Park Service, GNRA.
properties.SiteRestorationStatus: Hawtree Point was recommended in the draft HRE in 2017 but was removed from final consideration in HRE based on the outcome of the regional CE/ICA. The project can be implemented by others.
properties.CoastWetNote: Restoration of tidal marsh system with protective buffers. An existing patch of salt marsh hay will be excavated and re-planted. This area is currently being invaded by the surrounding invasive. Salt marsh hay will be planted in the location after the excavation and regrading of the surrounding land.
properties.IslandsNote: Hawtree Park is a major stopover point in the Atlantic Flyway for over 300 species of migratory shorebirds.
properties.ForestsNote: The project could include 1.7 acres of scrub/shrub and forested wetland. Some regrading and grubbing would remove the invasive species, and native grasses and shrubs will be planted at the site.
properties.AquaticHabNote: The habitat serves as nursery, feeding, spawning, and refuge sites for more than 80 anadromous and estuarine fish species; food sources for adult transient fish, hundreds of fish and wildlife species, invertebrates (horseshoe crabs and diamondback terrapin); endangered and threatened species (peregrine falcons, piping plovers, Atlantic Ridley sea turtles).
properties.ShoreNote: This project could include coastal dune restoration and shore protection in the form of toe dike protection, tidal pools, and natural plantings.
properties.TributaryNote: The basin will be recontoured to the mouth of Fresh Creek substantially improving flushing throughout the basin.
properties.SedimentNote: Any contaminated media identified during design phase would be capped.
properties.AccessNote: Hawtree Point is regularly used by ATVs that continually disturb the existing vegetation. This project would restore native plant communities and place boulders (permanent barriers) along the landside boundary of the site as a blockade to motorized vehicles.
properties.HabOther: Wetland intertidal shallows, low marsh, scrub-shrub/forested upland.
properties.Flora: Hawtree Point is dominated by non-native, invasive plant species. Within undeveloped portions of the larger site, the cover type consists of a high marsh community dominated by salt meadow cordgrass with patches of marsh elder and common reed. A narrow, ten-foot wide fringe of saltmarsh cordgrass is present along the channel edge. The smaller site to the south consists of unvegetated sediments and sparse stands of saltmarsh cordgrass. Patches of low marsh are present between buildings.
properties.UseDescrip: Wetland intertidal shallows, low marsh, scrub-shrub/forested upland make up the site. Some residential homes are present along the main channel that extends to the east. Several homes in this area appear to be abandoned. The site is zoned open/recreational site with federal land. The surrounding land is zoned vacant, 1 & 2 family residential, transportation/utilities, and open/recreational site.
properties.History: In the early 1900s, a canal was dug at the southern end of the Hawtree creek to create Hawtree Basin. Hawtree Point was filled during the development of the communities of Howard Beach and Hamilton Beach.
properties.OtherDescrip: The shoreline is characterized by pile and bulkhead supported houses that extend over the water along developed shoreline edges. Along undisturbed portions of the existing tidal marsh, the banks of the channels have a steep gradient that rises into the marsh. Narrow mud flats fringe the undeveloped tidal marshes at low tide. The soils consist of organic peat within the tidal marsh, and silts within the channel. It contains monotypic stands of nonnative invasive plant species and is continually disturbed by the use of all-terrain vehicles along the shoreline.
properties.NotesCLKS: christy, I couldn’t change name to hawtree point on part2…

properties.SiteRestorationStatus: Authorized for Construction in WRDA 2020, awaiting appropriations to initiate PED
properties.CoastWetNote: Design maximizes marsh habitat by creating a tidal channel in the northern portion of the site and re-grading the existing upland Phragmites stand to salt marsh elevations to create approximately 19 acres of low marsh, 5.4 acres of high marsh, 6.2 acres of scrub/shrub wetlands, 8 acres of uplands, and 2.3 acres/3,240 linear feet of tidal channel.
properties.IslandsNote: This site is a major stopover point in the Atlantic Flyway for over 300 species of migratory shorebirds.
properties.ForestsNote: Excavated sand will be used to create 8 acres of maritime forest on the northern portion of the site and excavated soil is planned to be placed at the southern portion of the site in coordination with the future potential NPS remedial action.
properties.AquaticHabNote: Habitat serves as nursery, feeding, spawning and refuge sites for more than 80 anadromous and estuarine fish species; food sources for adult transient fish, 100s of fish/wildlife species, invertebrates (horseshoe crabs and diamondback terrapin); endangered and threatened species (peregrine falcons, piping plovers, Atlantic Ridley sea turtles).
properties.ShoreNote: Shore protection strategies.
properties.TributaryNote: Channel modification/alignment. Stream geomorphology restoration
properties.SedimentNote: Sediment load reduction. Risks can be reduced and overall improvement can occur as a result of restoration action through use of cleaner areas for capping and grading at the surface.  Soil to be excavated in the north could be beneficially used in coordination with the cleanup of the southern portion of the site.
properties.AccessNote: Public education/access opportunities.
properties.HabOther: The ecological problems at Dead Horse Bay include:  covering of the historic marsh with fill, including the solid waste landfill in the southern project area placed after 1948, erosion and exposure of the solid waste landfill, steep bathymetry of the south.  HRE focused on the Northern portion of the site.
properties.Flora: The small patches of low marsh are dominated by saltmarsh cordgrass and grassland. Behind the narrow beach, the foreshore and bluff areas contain mostly grassland habitat dominated by common reed. Narrow bands dominated by beach grass and seaside goldenro
properties.Fauna: The area supports both black-crowned (Nycticorax nycticorax) and yellow-crowned night herons (Nyctanassa violacea). Clapper rails (Rallus longirostris) are heard here in warmer months while winter is a good time for spotting ducks.
properties.UseDescrip: The land is zoned an open/recreational site with federal land.
properties.History: Prior to 1941, this site was essentially undisturbed.  Most of the marsh area and the southern portion of the open water were covered by landfill by the NYC Parks Department in the 1950s.  In the northern portion of the site, the 1941 coastal chart shows site was covered with dredged material.
properties.OtherDescrip: This site consists of undeveloped parkland within the GNRA maintained by the NPS. The shoreline consists mostly of a narrow sandy beach with a few small patches of low marsh located along the central portion of the western shoreline.
properties.Contact: USACE: Lisa Baron (lisa.a.baron@usace.army.mil); NPS: Patricia Rafferty (Patricia_Rafferty@nps.gov)

properties.SiteRestorationStatus:
Restoration Opportunity
The City of New York, with leadership from the local communtiy board, proposes the creation of a connected greenway along the industrial or vacant waterfront of the north and east shorelines of Staten Island. The greenway proposal includes contaminant remediation, wetland and shoreline restoration, and recreational improvements.

The North Shore Waterfront Conservancy, in collaboration with NYC Parks and the Trust for Public Land, propose a new park along the north shore waterfront to improve public access, recreation, and restore wetland and riparian zones.

properties.SiteRestorationStatus:
Restoration Opportunity 
Billion Oyster Project is working with the Brooklyn Navy Yard to install in Wallabout Channel an Eco-Dock for oyster monitoring events as well as an oyster nursery.
properties.DevelDescrip: 1 - Wallabout Channel is part of the Brooklyn Navy Yard.
properties.UseDescrip: Transportation, vacant lot, industrial and parking with surround lots zoned residential, mixed use
properties.History: Wallabout Bay is a small body of water in Upper New York Bay along the northwest shore of the New York City borough of Brooklyn, between the present Williamsburg and Manhattan Bridges. Wallabout Bay is now the site of the Brooklyn Navy Yard. A the northwestern corner of this property, a deep channel, Wallabout Channel, cuts inland as the only remnant of Wallabout Creek.

properties.PlanRegion: HARLEM RIVER, EAST RIVER, & WESTERN LONG ISLAND SOUND STUDY AREA
properties.LocationDescrip: Northern shore of Randall's Island between the Harlem and East River.
properties.CoastWetNote: This project can create several acres of salt marsh habitat (in particular, low marsh composed of saltwater cordgrass) which currently does not exist within the Kill.
properties.IslandsNote: Creating new salt marsh habitat will create new foraging areas for wading birds. The Bronx Kill is located in close proximity to North and South Brother Island, two areas that are known to have large populations of nesting wading birds.
properties.ForestsNote: This project will also create areas of upland maritime buffer. A narrow upland buffer composed of native trees, shrubs, and grasses can provide nesting, foraging, and breeding habitat for song birds, mammals, butterflies, and dragonflies.
properties.AquaticHabNote: Salt marsh, in particular low marsh, will provide habitat for vertebrates and invertebrates. Fiddler crabs will make create borrows among the mudflat of the low marsh and small fish will feed and rest among the grasses.
properties.ShoreNote: Currently, the shoreline is composed of rock rip-rap which offers little ecosystem benefits. Replacing this shoreline with a softened edge and gradual slope will provide ecosystem  benefits as well as accommodate the expected sea level rise.
properties.WaterNote: RWG Enclosed and combined waterbodies list
properties.AccessNote: The creation of kayak/canoe launch will offer new opportunities for recreation at Randall's Island. It will also offer new opportunities for environmental education in the surrounding under served communities of East Harlem and the South Bronx.
properties.Flora: Small patches of saltwater cordgrass and marsh elder within the rip-rap shoreline. Eastern cottonwoods, sumac, goldenrod, and mugwort in the adjacent upland.
properties.Fauna: Great blue heron, great egret, yellow crowned night heron, black crowned night heron, fiddler crab, ribbed mussel, mud snails, northern shovelers, mallards, striped bass, mummichogs, and silversides have been spotted within or along the the Kill.
properties.KnownContaminates: Rock rip-rap shoreline and CSO outfall on the northern bank of the Kill. Historical dumping has occurred.

properties.DEnvironment: Environmental investigations preformed by Kiviat and McDonald 2002. A sediment/vegetation comparative study was performed in 2003. Wetland assessment performed in 2003.

properties.PlanRegion: NEWARK BAY, HACKENSACK & PASSAIC RIVERS STUDY AREA
properties.LocationDescrip:
Kearny Point is located at the convergence of the Hackensack and Passaic rivers at river mile 0.
(Size: 3000ft. X 1600ft.)
properties.SiteRestorationStatus: Kearny Point was recommended in the draft HRE in 2017 but was removed from final consideration in HRE due to changes in the future without project condition. During the planning process, remedial actions were conducted at this site by other agencies which preclude USACE actions at the site.
properties.CoastWetNote: Emergent wetland creation including 17.8 acres of low marsh and 2.5 acres of high marsh.
properties.ForestsNote: Creation of 6.6 acres of scrub and shrub/forested wetland and 7 acres of maritime buffer forest.
properties.AquaticHabNote: Removal of invasive species, man-made debris and unused structures will help to restore connections between mudflats, shorelines and wetlands.
properties.ShoreNote: Bank stabilization along a portion of the shoreline along Newark Bay. Removing the riprap and bulkhead and re-grading the shoreline.
properties.TributaryNote: 3,404 LF of tidal channel and streambank restoration
properties.SedimentNote: USEPA Remedial Action followed by Restoration. Potential dredging and/or capping of contaminated sediment based on sediment sampling.
properties.AccessNote: Opportunity for several public access points exists at this site including an elevated path system that spans several habitats and leads to a boat launch.
properties.HabOther: The site is dominated by invasive species in the Lower Passaic River. It contains a forested area on the eastern half of the site which is the location of an active bald eagle nest.
properties.Flora: Undeveloped forest.
properties.Fauna: An active bald eagle nest is found at this site.
properties.DevelDescrip: The surrounding environment consists entirely of commercial developments and roadways.  Adjacent commercial developments include Hudson County Correctional Center and River Terminal, which is a massive distribution warehouse.
properties.UseDescrip: This site is currently used as a vacant lot, former industrial site.
properties.History: The Kearny Point restoration site is a decommissioned industrial facility built entirely of historic fill. The Kearny Point upland portion of the site was remediated in 2015 which was found to prevent future restoration on-site.
properties.KnownContaminates: USEPA Remedial Action.
properties.OtherDescrip:
The Kearny Point restoration site is a decommissioned industrial facility built entirely of historic fill.
Baseline Conditions and Water Resource Problems at Kearny Point:
• The Kearny Point restoration site is a decommissioned industrial facility
properties.ASurvey: USGS digital raster graphics maps and NJDEP Regional Data Inclusive of this site.
properties.BHistory: BASF Corporation, Town of Kearny, Havenick Associates. Former chemical manufacturing facility.
properties.CFauna: Winter and summer fish sampling, one time benthic community sampling (1, 19).
properties.DEnvironment: Salt marsh containing Spartina alterniflora exists along both sides of the point, particularly the east side (Shisler, 2004) (2, 19).
properties.EGeotechnical: Sediment characterization in 1995, 1996 and 2005 by Aqua Survey (3). No data above high tide.
properties.GWater: Newark Bay Estuary Sediment Characterization 1990-1993 (4), limited surface water quality and sediment data from Passaic River Study Area Investigations (5, 6), Water Quality NJHDG 2002-present (7)

properties.PlanRegion: NEWARK BAY, HACKENSACK & PASSAIC RIVERS STUDY AREA
properties.LocationDescrip:
Located in the industrial district north of Port Newark, this site is situated on the west bank of the Newark Bay at river mile 0.
(Size: 8400ft. X 2700ft.)
properties.SiteRestorationStatus: Authorized for Construction in WRDA 2020, awaiting appropriations to initiate PED
properties.CoastWetNote: Emergent wetland creation including 5.3 acres of low marsh and 0.9 acres of high marsh.
properties.ForestsNote: Restoration of 2.9 acres of coastal maritime Forest and 0.4 acres of scrub shrub wetland creation. Stabilization of riparian forest.
properties.AquaticHabNote: Creation of habitat connectivity along new mudflats/tidal channels.
properties.ShoreNote: Shoreline/bank Stabilization and streambank restoration
properties.TributaryNote: Restoration of 1.4 acres of new tidal channels. Removal of man-made debris and unused structures (tide gate), re-connection of water from the river to wetlands and southern creek.
properties.SedimentNote: USEPA Remedial Action required prior to restoration. Potential dredging and/or capping of contaminated sediment based on sediment sampling.
properties.AccessNote: Improved public access to water and increased opportunities for boating, hiking, education, and passive recreation by upgrading existing pedestrian path and replacing portion of path with pier deck system on southern perimeter of property (3,711 lf).
properties.HabOther: The Oak Island Yards restoration site contains Newark’s largest extent of tidal marsh, tidal creeks, and palustrine emergent wetland in the Passaic River. This estuarine ecosystem is documented to have historic fill, vacant structural elements, debris in the tidal channel, and unused pipelines running throughout. The site is dominated by non-native invasive vegetation, limiting ecological value.
properties.Flora: The dominant vegetative species are invasive Phragmites, mugwart and sumac.
properties.Fauna: Faunal species include 3 types of birds and 2 mammals.
properties.UseDescrip: Vacant lot. Former Industrial site.  This site is located along approximately 900 feet of Newark Bay and is bordered by a shipping container yard, railroad tracks, and a HESS petroleum tank farm. A semi-tidal ditch with a tide gate is located adjacent to the site, below the railroad track embankment on the southeast border of the site. Since the date of the project mapping aerial photo, the shipping container storage yard has been extended southeast to within approximately 100 feet of the pond and runs the full width of the northwestern boundary of the site. Also, a considerable amount of rock and gravel fill has been placed onsite since the aerial photo was taken. Rock fill extends from the shipping containers all the way to the river along the southeast portion of the site and has also been placed in the river. The remainder of the site is vegetated.
properties.KnownContaminates: USEPA Remedial Action.
properties.OtherDescrip:
Oak Island Yards contains Newark’s largest extent of tidal marsh, tidal creeks, and palustrine emergent wetland.  This estuarine ecosystem is documented to have historic fill, build up of vacant structural elements, debris in the tidal channel, and unused pipelines running throughout the project.
This site has been identified as a Potential Environmental Justice Area (PEJA) based on NYSDEC criteria.

and are characterized by the presence of invasive vegetation. Three (3) ponds, created by weirs, suffer from algal blooms and eutrophication indicative of excess nutrient inputs. Degradation of the site will continue in

properties.PlanRegion: NEWARK BAY, HACKENSACK & PASSAIC RIVERS STUDY AREA
HARLEM RIVER, EAST RIVER, & WESTERN LONG ISLAND SOUND STUDY AREA
properties.Ownership: NYC DPR, NYD Dept. of Small Business
properties.CoastWetNote: Currently, the site has no wetlands, and any gain in wetlands would be considered a net gain in acreage. There are, however, successfully restored wetlands across the Harlem River along the Randall’s Island waterfront edge (Randall's Island Park Alliance).
properties.AquaticHabNote: Re-creation of an intertidal zone and shallow water pools will provide the kind of habitat that will enable these kinds of organisms to thrive. The proposed expanded intertidal zone and shallow pools will provide habitat for key prey species and nursery habitat for young fish.
properties.ShoreNote: Addressing this TEC gets to the heart of the reason for implementing the ecological edge study. This project aims primarily to establish shoreline and shallow habitat in the area of focus. This goal is a sensitive redesign of a landmass that is integrated into the existing marine habitat, thus re-creating a vibrant riparian zone, inter-tidal zone, and illuminated shallow water pools. This variety of re-created living shoreline habitat will then enable plant life, land based wildlife, and marine life to establish itself in a symbiotically integrated and newly created waterfront edge habitat.
properties.AccessNote: As previously stated, direct water access is not possible because of the conventional bulkhead wall that abuts the river’s edge and blocks people from literally reaching the water. Moreover, there are very few access points that connect the upland to the edge of the waterfront over the FDR Drive. There are two within the parameters of the project, at 103rd Street and 111th Street, and there is only one access point to Randall’s Island and that is located at 103rd Street. Randall’s Island does offer increased opportunity for recreational and water based activities, but it is even less accessible than the Esplanade with the single access point from northern Manhattan. The hope is that an ecological edge on the Harlem side of the Harlem River will give direct access to the water to the residents of this underserved community that deserve the benefit of experiencing the water and learning from it. We envision an integrated learning center that marries oversight of the ecological edge with educational opportunities to learn about and become stewards for the site. The goal is for the community to become invested in protecting this re-introduced piece of nature that can both teach and protect them. Practically, in addition to education, a living shoreline will also increase opportunities for fishing and human powered boating.
properties.Flora: Currently primarily plants associated with NYC Parks Greenway - there are several mature trees in varying condition, and they are interspersed with low scale, intermittent shrubbery. The site also has a previous, pre-industrial development history as an area characterized by low-lying marshes along the Harlem River, with creeks draining to it from sections of Northern Manhattan
properties.Fauna: The upland fauna is virtually non-existent due to the starkness of the habitat – the near presence of the FDR Drive and the hardened bulkhead edge of the Harlem River, with a narrow and deteriorating pathway in between.
properties.UseDescrip: Vacant Lot, park, public access, passive recreation.
properties.History: Early on, the river’s edge was characterized by outcroppings of natural stone, vegetated earthen banks, and low-lying marshes. With industrial development, the site was filled in and the edge hardened to accommodate the shipping industry. This effectively severed the waterfront from the adjacent neighborhoods and urban fabric as a whole.  (Mathews Nielsen Landscape Architects, P.C., East River Esplanade Vision Plan,New York, NY: Mathews Nielsen Landscape Architects, P.C., 2014 Print. p. 7)
properties.KnownContaminates: There are multiple CSOs along the length of the site, and the water quality is impacted by pollution, experiencing periodically high fecal coliform levels and low dissolved oxygen levels based on testing to date.

properties.OtherDescrip: Shoelace Park site is located along the Bronx River and is surrounded by dense, urban development. The site is characterized by an over-widened channel with steep vertical banks and eroded shoreline. Stream banks are sparsely vegetated and wetlands are limited to very narrow, dispersed strips of emergent vegetation. The wetlands and large portions of the upland riverine corridor provide low quality upland buffer and are dominated by invasive species. Stream habitat is also degraded by poor water quality and increased sediment load.

properties.History: Flushing Creek was impacted by the land development associated with the New York World’s Fair of 1939-1940. Site hydrology was altered with the creation of Willow and Meadow Lakes and also the channelization of Flushing Creek. Bathymetric changes in support of navigation or from aggregate mining can influence estuarine systems and their outer beaches. These impacts include alterations of water circulation (Malhadas et al., 2009; Meyers et al., 2014; ValleLevinson and Lwiza, 1995) and near shore tidal range (Wong and Wilson, 1979), offshore sediment transport processes (Kelley et al., 2004; Kortkaas et al., 2010), deprivation of littoral replenishment material (Kraus and Galgano, 2001), and alteration of biological communities (Byrnes et al., 2004).
properties.OtherDescrip: The width of the creek varies greatly from about 400 ft wide near Shea Stadium to approximately 3,000 ft across at LaGuardia Airport in the bay. Flushing Creek is within a PEJA identified by NYSDEC. Flushing Creek and is roughly two miles upstream from the East River. Previously a sinuous tidal creek in an extensive tidal wetland system, the site suffers from significant straightening of the stream, filled and degraded wetlands, and eroded shorelines dominated by invasive species. Poor water quality limits the diversity of fish and benthic communities. NYCDEP has improved water quality as part of their Long Term Control Plan which will ensure the sustainability of future restoration of the site. The site would continue to be degraded and characterized by invasive species in the future.

properties.History: The former Nuodex site is a 185-acre parcel on the Raritan River in Woodbridge, New Jersey. A portion of the site (approximately 50 acres) was used for clay mining from the 1800s through early 1900s. Several chemical manufacturers then used the site until the mid-1980s. The other portion (approximately 135 acres) was historically undeveloped (including three ponds and 81 acres of jurisdictional wetlands) although highly impacted by historic releases, fill and disposal of contaminated dredge spoils. In 2010, the RAWP was submitted to NJDEP and included on-site containment of approximately 70 acres using a subsurface hydraulic barrier wall, groundwater extraction and treatment and soil cap, with limited excavation and off-site disposal of “hot spots,” requiring the filling and capping of ponds and wetlands. To compensate for the loss of these ecological resources, the remedial action also included ecological enhancement, restoration and preservation of approximately 100 acres of an open water pond feature, wetlands and enhanced uplands including an “eco park” for public access. The inclusion of the site within the BDA facilitated productive, timely input from the NJDEP, the U.S. Army Corp of Engineers (USACE), the Town of Woodbridge and other stakeholders, and expedited the design, permitting and approval of the remedial action. The RAWP was approved by the NJDEP in March of 2011; the primary NJDEP and USACE permits were received and remedial activities initiated in June and September of 2011.

NJDEP does not concur with the decision to take no action; however, it is USACE’s position that these constituents are not attributable to a DoD-documented release and that no action is protective of public health or welfare and the environment from actual or threatened CERCLA releases of DoD-related hazardous substances. According to the ACOE, No remedial action is necessary at this site. No further action allows for UU/UE. Per 40 CFR 300.430(f)(4)(ii), five-year reviews are a requirement only for alternatives not allowing for UU/UE. Therefore, a five-year review will not be required. properties.History: O’Neill Properties bought the Sayreville site for $80 million in 2008, some two decades after it was abandoned by NL Industries, formerly National Lead, which had manufactured paint pigment there since 1934. In early 2014, the Environmental Protection Agency directed the company to pay $79 million to clean up a 40-acre lagoon on the east side of the site. NL Industries was found to be at least partly responsible for contamination there, which included PCBs, titanium dioxide and technologically enhanced naturally occurring radioactive material. This required a multiyear environmental remediation project costing $45 million, and involving the removal or treatment of 360,000 cubic yards of soil.

Restoration Opportunity:
New York Restoration Project (NYRP), in partnership with NYC Parks, began the installation of a Living Shoreline project at Sherman Creek in mid-2019. The project includes an inter-tidal oyster reef (concrete oyster castles) and wetland restoration. Billion Oyster Project seeks to expand these installations with additional oyster castles with funding from NYRP.

properties.LocationDescrip: 0.1 miles northwest of the intersection of Gordon Road and Museum Road, Old Bridge Township, Middlesex County, NJ.
properties.Ownership: NJDEP, under the supervision of the state Division of Parks and Forestry.
properties.CoastWetNote: Preservation of saltwater and freshwater marsh habitat. Assessment of wetland for potential fill removal, invasive species and replanting the area with native vegetation, regrading the marsh and tidal channel to improve tidal hydrology. Assessment for sto
properties.ForestsNote: Preservation and restoration of Pine Barrens and Northeast Hardwood forest. Support to State Park Atlantic White Cedar Swamp preservation.
properties.TributaryNote: Assessment of culverts at Garden State Parkway crossing. Assessment for potential fish passage project at Hook Lake. Historically, this is a confirmed spawning site (Durkas 1991).
properties.SedimentNote: Potential removal/capping of contaminated sediment based on testing.
properties.AccessNote: Support ongoing State Park public access efforts.
properties.HabOther: This site is natural and undeveloped containing open waterways, floodplains and swamp bogs. It does contain a culvert, correcting stream flow.
properties.Flora: Cheesequake State Park contains a diverse mix of hardwood forest, Atlantic white cedar swamp, and pineland. In New Jersey, Atlantic White Cedar is the only obligate wetland tree species. It is found mainly in the Pine Barrens, but also occurs in isolated
properties.Fauna: The park brings a range of easily accessible habitat with  highly visible osprey nests.  Hook lake is stocked every spring with brook and rainbow trout, and often in fall again with channel catfish. A resident fishery also includes largemouth bass, perch, and sunfish.
properties.UseDescrip: Open space, passive recreation, state park.
properties.OtherDescrip: Cheesequake State Park is situated in the middle of the urban north and the suburban south, it lies in a transitional zone between two different ecosystems, adding to the birding diversity. Open fields, saltwater and freshwater marshes, a white cedar swamp are additional ecosystems.  The park is adjacent to the Hook’s Creek tidal marsh area, but the lake was isolated from tidal influence in 1984 via the placement of an embankment dam across the channel.
properties.GWater: NJDEP 2003.
properties.Notes: Combined with white cedar swamp and hook lake

properties.PlanRegion: HARLEM RIVER, EAST RIVER, & WESTERN LONG ISLAND SOUND STUDY AREA
properties.LocationDescrip: The Westchester County Center site is bounded by the southbound lanes of the Bronx River Parkway to the west, the Metro North right-of-way to the east, and the Westchester County Center East Parking lot to the south.
properties.SiteRestorationStatus: Westchester County Center was recommended in the draft HRE in 2017 but was removed from final consideration in HRE based on the outcome of the regional CE/ICA. The project can be implemented by others.
properties.FreshWetNote: Creation of approximately 4.9 acres of emergent wetland.
properties.ForestsNote: This project contains approximately 3.8 acres of invasive species removal and native planting.
properties.AquaticHabNote: Improved habitat for anadromous species.
properties.TributaryNote: This restoration site is traversed by the Bronx River and includes the confluence of two tributaries, the Manhattan Brook and Fulton Brook. This project includes channel realignment with in-stream structures, bed restoration, bank stabilization, and construction of channel plugs at upstream and downstream ends of the channel.
properties.SedimentNote: Installation of sediment basins in the Manhattan Brook and Fulton Brook confluences.
properties.AccessNote: Westchester County Center is a public facility, which would provide key educational opportunities and demonstrate the USACE’s commitment to urban ecosystem restoration. Construction of a new paved path to divert pedestrian traffic away from the created emergent wetlands.
properties.HabOther: Undisturbed wetland and upland habitats are sparse and dispersed across the largely maintained park. Much of the park consists of right-of-way lawns and largely of nonnative, invasive species. The stream is subject to strong and high flows during storm events causing active erosion on the banks, sediment deposits, and collection of garbage and debris.
properties.Flora: Clusters of trees and Japanese knotweed and vines dominate this site.
properties.UseDescrip: Westchester County Center is a largely maintained park.
properties.OtherDescrip:
Baseline Conditions and Water Resource Problems:
-The Westchester County Center site has large tracts of maintained lawn with trees. The topography is generally flat with the Bronx River flowing through the middle of the site.
-The stream is subject to strong and high flows that cause active erosion, sediment deposits, and collection of garbage and debris.

- River Park/West Farm Rapids Park is approximately 900 feet in length, bisected by 180th Street, located within a densely populated, urban area.

properties.PlanRegion: JAMAICA BAY STUDY AREA
properties.LocationDescrip: The Jamaica Bay Marsh Islands are located in the USDOI National Park Service Gateway National Recreation Area. Elders Center Marsh Island is located in northern Jamaica Bay, .5 miles west of Cross Bay Boulevard, Kings County, NY.
properties.SiteRestorationStatus: Authorized for Construction in WRDA 2020, awaiting appropriations to initiate PED
properties.CoastWetNote: Marsh islands have been disappearing and a loss of more than 2000 acres have been documented since 1924 and will continue to be lost at an alarming rate. Project restores total 34 acres marsh island habitat (low marsh [15.2 acres], high marsh [10.9 acres], scrub/shrub [1.4 acres], tidal channels [1 acres], shallows [5.5 acres]) following placement of 284,891 CY clean sand.
properties.IslandsNote: The rapidly eroding marsh islands of Jamaica Bay (a Significant Habitat Complex of the New York Bight Watershed) provide important nesting habitat for 300 bird species.
properties.AquaticHabNote: Habitat serves as nursery, feeding, spawning and refuge sites for more than 80 anadromous and estuarine fish species; food sources for adult transient fish, 100s of fish/wildlife species, invertebrates (horseshoe crabs and diamondback terrapin); endangered and threatened species (peregrine falcons, piping plovers, Atlantic Ridley sea turtles).
properties.ShoreNote: Grading of sand (284,891 CY) to restore estuarine sub-tidal habitat, intertidal mudflat and shallow water (5.5 acres) habitats.
properties.SedimentNote: Placement of clean sand (284,891 CY)
properties.HabOther:
Significance of Restoration in the Region and at the Site:
-Surrounded by heavily urbanized and densely populated areas of Brooklyn and Queens, including JFK International Airport, there is little remaining habitat suitable for avian and marine wildlife.  Islands provide significant coastal storm risk management benefits for the surrounding communities.
properties.Flora: there is currently no habitat at Elders Center
properties.UseDescrip: Elders Center Marsh Island is part of GNRA. The land is zoned an open recreational site with federal land.
properties.History: Elders Point Marsh was historically one (1) island but marsh loss in the center of the island created two (2) distinct islands separated by a mud flat (USACE, 2006). Elders Point East and West were restored with 40 acres of marsh island each.  At that time it was infeasible to restore Elders Center based on the depth of the substrate in that area. Presently, no marsh island exists above water between the 2 islands.
properties.KnownContaminates: Area will be capped with clean sand from navigation program
properties.OtherDescrip: Elders Point Marsh was historically one (1) island but marsh loss in the center of the island created two (2) distinct islands separated by a mud flat (USACE, 2006). When the restoration of Elders Point East and Elders Point West were planned and implemented, it was infeasible to restore Elders Center based on the depth of the substrate in that area. Presently, no marsh island exists above water between the 2 islands.
properties.Contact: USACE: Lisa Baron (lisa.a.baron@usace.army.mil); NYCDEP: John McLaughlin (JohnM@dep.nyc.gov)

properties.Address: Bridge Park, west of Depot Place from the Alexander Hamilton Bridge to the High Bridge.
properties.LocationDescrip:
Site is bounded by the Harlem River to the west, Depot Place to the east, the Alexander Hamilton Bridge to the
north, and the High Bridge to the south.
properties.Ownership: NYC Department of Parks and Recreation
properties.SiteRestorationStatus: No restoration actions have occurred to date.
properties.CoastWetNote:
The project will create a naturalized shoreline and riparian marsh habitat over 1.01 acres, improving the ecological
function of the Harlem River region.
properties.ShoreNote: The project will restore shoreline along Harlem River.
properties.AccessNote:
The project will improve public waterfront access in an area that is currently underutilized and where limited
access exists.
properties.HabOther: Forest, Estuarine
properties.Flora:
Upland areas are characterized by invasive vegetation,
such as mugwort, porcelain berry, and Ailanthus.
properties.Fauna:
Not known, but likely pollution and disturbance
tolerant rodents, birds and insects.
properties.DevelDescrip:
Site currently consists of a rip rap shoreline and upland vegetation, with paved areas most recently used as
construction staging for the High Bridge project.
properties.KnownContaminates:
The Harlem River was designated as a NYC Brownfield Opportunity Area in April 2015. Local soils
conditions are unknown but likely contaminated, since the site consists of fill. Paved surfaces as well as fill and
debris are present on site. The shoreline i

properties.PlanRegion: HARLEM RIVER, EAST RIVER, & WESTERN LONG ISLAND SOUND STUDY AREA
properties.Address: Bridge Park, west of Depot Place from the Alexander Hamilton Bridge to the High Bridge.
properties.LocationDescrip:
Coastal wetlands restoration is proposed on the west shore of Hammond Cove, located east of Pennyfield Avenue
from Chaffee Avenue to Giegerich Place. Maritime forest restoration is proposed on the east shore of Hammond
Cove, located west of Longstreet Ave
properties.Ownership: NYC Department of Parks and Recreation
properties.ProtectedInfo:
Parcels are owned by the NYC Department of Parks and Recreation but encroachments have been observed and
reported.
properties.SiteRestorationStatus: No restoration actions have occurred to date., recent dredging at the north end marina
properties.CoastWetNote:
The project will restore 0.75 acres of low and high marsh habitat, improving the ecological function of existing
coastal wetland habitat in the area in a region of accelerated marsh loss.
properties.ForestsNote:
Restoration activities, including removal of debris, management of invasive vines, and planting of native
understory will occur over 3.8 acres.
properties.ShoreNote: The project will restore shoreline and provide shallows in the HRE region.
properties.HabOther: Hab for fish crabs and lobsters, estuarine
properties.Flora:
The east side of Hammond Cove is characterized by
salt marsh and adjacent coastal scrub-shrubland interspersed with fill, mowed lawn, and areas of illegal dumping.
The west side consists of coastal forest that has been subject to dumping and invasion by e
properties.Fauna:
Not known, but likely pollution and disturbance
tolerant rodents, birds and insects.
properties.DevelDescrip:
Existing wetland and maritime forest habitat with private infrastructure encroachments, including fencing, docks,
lawns, and driveways.
properties.History:
Site contains former wetland based on 1974 NYSDEC tidal wetland, recent incursions and destruction of marsh grass on eastern side
extents.
properties.KnownContaminates:
Degraded site dominated by invasive plant species and subject to dumping. Soil conditions are not yet
known. Human alterations to the natural landscape, including the installation of turf lawns, fill embankments, and
rock revetments, have fragmented tidal
properties.OtherDescrip:
Hammonds Cove Marina also operates at the site. DEC is facilitating dredging at
the mouth of Hammonds Cove with funding for dredging from the local Councilmember. If the dredge material is
determined to be clean, it might be a site at which to pilot sand

properties.PlanRegion: ARTHUR KILL/KILL VAN KULL STUDY AREA
properties.Address: Snug Harbor Cultural Center between Snug Harbor Road and Richmond Terrace
properties.LocationDescrip: Site is bounded by Snug Harbor Road to the east, south, and west, and Richmond Terrace to the north.
properties.Ownership: NYC Department of Parks and Recreation
properties.SiteRestorationStatus:
Excavate fill and remove trees to reestablish salt marsh throughout site, to be accomplished in phases as funding
allows. Initial small-scale restoration would include breaching low levees on stream banks, clearing and grubbing to
a maximum of 6 inches, w
properties.CoastWetNote:
The project will restore salt marsh habitat over 1.25 acres, improving the ecological function of a channelized
tidal stream.
properties.ForestsNote:
The project will remove invasive vegetation and restore native scrub-shrub and maritime forest habitat over 3.3
acres.
properties.AccessNote:
The site can also provide opportunities for environmental education and citizen stewardship through partnership
with the Snug Harbor Cultural Center.
properties.HabOther: Upland, shrub scrub
properties.Flora:
Stream with narrow strip of high marsh herbaceous
and shrubs species on banks, with salt-tolerant species beyond the banks. Phragmites present beyond the salt
marsh, and black willow, hackberry, and a mix of native and invasive species, including knotweed
properties.Fauna:
Not known, but likely pollution and disturbance
tolerant rodents, birds and insects.
properties.DevelDescrip:
The proposed opportunity is on undeveloped land located at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center and Botanic
Garden.
properties.History:
The Snug Harbor Cultural Center was the former site of Sailors Snug
Harbor, a home for retired sailors that was founded in 1801. The City Landmarks Preservation Commission has
designated eight of the structures on site as official landmarks. The cultural
properties.KnownContaminates: Soils contamination unknown. Low level fill is present across the site.

properties.PlanRegion: ARTHUR KILL/KILL VAN KULL STUDY AREA
properties.LocationDescrip: .5 miles west of I-95, .75 miles east of US Highway 1
properties.Flora: Extensive Phragmites stands.
properties.OtherDescrip: Degraded wetland.

properties.PlanRegion: HARLEM RIVER, EAST RIVER, & WESTERN LONG ISLAND SOUND STUDY AREA
properties.LocationDescrip: Northeast College Point, adjacent to East River
properties.SiteRestorationStatus: Part of property on NW side of Powels Cove where DEP gave property to DPR is in design for access and rehabilitation.
properties.CoastWetNote: Potential marsh build out, Access
properties.Flora: Mostly tidal wetland with some low-lying uplands. Former salt marsh filled to create uplands.  Currently dominated by Phragmites and other invasive species.
properties.OtherDescrip: Pockets of standing water may facilitate freshwater mosquito breeding.
properties.NotesCLKS: unresolved - move info to project of CRPID 174, polygon removed from site table, add polygon to project table
